author: bunni xoxo

text:
On the Playstation version of "Soul Edge" (original Japanese version), each character had three musical themes, the original arcade music, an arranged version of the arcade music and a Khan Super Session track which you can hear in this video, "A Continental Gale" was Rock's theme.

Most of the Khan Super Session tracks were done by live performing musicians, hence the great sounding quality.

text: im in the process of doing so but i must say that it is hands down one of the hardest things i ever tried to do....i have a lot of experience under my belt when it come to fighting games...and Virtua Fighter is a challenge...i have wolf down for sure but it wasnt easy at all man
author: Khary Williamson

text: I have a tone of respect for anyone who can master just one character in Virtua Fighter; its depth is staggering.
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: There were some balance issues in DOA series, even in the latest installment. certain characters have a ridiculous advantage. I overlooked it though, because it doesn't make them unbeatable, its just something you have to be mindful of when versing them. DOA 4 online would have been a lot better if it had more content. SC4 was a major online disappointment for me. The game play speed has been knocked down a peg or three, making it less responsive than DOA4. :(
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: that game could not spoil me.....after i played it...it was ok but to weird....and they gave some characters more priority than others and i ddnt like that...i like virtua fighter better...i almost got spoiled by that game....then i started to play street fighter and king of fighters religiously again..lol
author: Khary Williamson

text: well, with developers like Team Ninja disbanding the lead member of the team for ambiguous reasons, it gives one a sore impression on the battle ground that is the video game industry.
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: I was also discovering DOA 3 and DOA Ultimate at the time, thus I was probably spoiled by its smooth, fast paced and brutal game play. :)
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: maybe I was too quick to discredit SC3. It was a good fighting game but not as solid as it could have been. the major draw for me was the create a character mode but beyond that innovation was lacking. The music added a little content to the fights but nothing memorable. It was like namco was trying too hard to make a sale and neglected the beauty and substance of the original game.  Just my opinion. admittedly when it first came out I was pretty excited until the newness wore off.
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: and i really dnt think SC3 was bad at all...music wise or gameplay wise....SC4 should of came out in at least another yr before they came out with it because to me it just seem it was still in the concept stage....at least with SC3 all of their ideas were fully developed and the gameplay was pretty solid...tales of the souls was also enjoyable for me....if anything SC4 would seem like the worst out of the series
author: Khary Williamson

text: yes it does sound shallow...and i did mention they fired the namco sound team...but i also mentioned that me next part was a theory at the end of my first comment....but im not holding it past them if they did it or not because of it has happend before....Capcom like i mention fired their sub company clover studios for undisclosed reason...and they were pumping out alot of hits...and ppl think the same think that may of happened to the NST may of happen to clover studios
author: Khary Williamson

text: as well as SC 4, more of a disappointment than 3.
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: Are you sure thats true, it just sounds a little shallow. I always knew the musical composition was watered down after the age of tekken 2 and soul blade, but if namco fired the sound team thats where they lost a sale. Soul Calibur 3 was a major disappointment for me in terms of music and game play.
author: Miyamoto Musashi

text: agreed....but i think namco caught on and kept most of the music like this for soul caliber....tekken was totally changed up...bt at least its not crappy techno....and some of the newer tekken games have went back to the way the music used to be like...and thats pretty awesome....you know the same think happen in capcom...bt it wasnt the sound team,,,it was a whole damn sub company
author: Khary Williamson

text: Wow, if that's true. That's weak sauce.
author: Orions Angel

text: because they fired the original namco sound team.....if you listen to some of the music in the earlier games up to tekken 2 that was the bese music in any of their games now because of that sound team.....all of the sudden when tekken 3 came out they had a different sound team.....no one knows why but think namco got  jealous that the sound team was getting more recognition for the games because of their music and namco let them because of it...just a theory
